title: Chott el Fejej
text:
Chott el Fejej, also known as Chott el Fedjedj and Chott el Fejaj, is a long, narrow inlet of the <a href="endorheic">endorheic</a> <a href="salt%20lake">salt lake</a> <a href="Chott%20el%20Djerid">Chott el Djerid</a> in southern <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>.
History and geography.
The bottom of Chott el Fejej lies below sea level and runs in a narrow path from the main body of Chott el Djerid to the Tunisian desert <a href="oasis">oasis</a> of <a href="El%20Hamma">El Hamma</a>, near the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Gab%C3%A8s">Gulf of Gabès</a> on the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. The distance from the point where the Chott el Fejej joins the Chott el Djerid to its end near El Hamma is approximately . Along its length, Chott el Fejej never widens beyond and in many places is considerably more narrow. The easterly end of the Chott el Fejej is separated from Mediterranean by an approximately wide ridge of sand near El Hamma.
It was this narrow sandy ridge, separating the Chott el Fejej from the Mediterranean Sea, which brought it to the attention of various geographers, engineers and diplomats. These figures looked to create an inland "<a href="Sahara%20Sea">Sahara Sea</a>" by channelling the waters of the Mediterranean into Sahara Desert basins which lay below sea level. A noted proposal to this effect was put forward in the late 1800s by French geographer <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois%20%C3%89lie%20Roudaire">François Élie Roudaire</a> and the creator of the Suez Canal, <a href="Ferdinand%20de%20Lesseps">Ferdinand de Lesseps</a>, but stalled after the French government withdrew funding. Later proposals, made as part of <a href="Operation%20Plowshare">Operation Plowshare</a>, posited that <a href="peaceful%20nuclear%20explosions">nuclear explosives</a> could be used to dig the proposed canal from the Mediterranean to the Chott el Fejej and other below-sea-level basins of the Sahara; these proposals were also fruitless.
Geology.
The Chott el Fejej is a typical <a href="chott">chott</a>, or dry lake, of the Sahara. It is underlain, however, by a major <a href="anticline">anticline</a> known as the <a href="Fejej%20Dome">Fejej Dome</a>. This anticline and other surrounding structures are argued to be the result of <a href="rifting">rifting</a> in the <a href="Cretaceous">Cretaceous</a> period.
